@graph.headline: I am not happy with IP Australia - what can I do? - IP First Response
@graph.creditText: IP First Response initiative led by IP Australia

audience.audienceType: Small and medium businesses, startups, and individuals

@graph.usageInfo: This information is general in nature and should not be relied upon as legal advice. You should seek independent professional advice relevant to your specific circumstances.

@graph.name: I am not happy with IP Australia - what can I do?
@graph.description:
If you are not happy with the service you received from IP Australia, there are ways you can raise your concerns. A complaint allows you to explain what went wrong and what outcome you would like.

@graph.name: What is it?
@graph.text:
If you are not happy with the service you received from IP Australia, there are ways you can raise your concerns. A complaint allows you to explain what went wrong and what outcome you would like. 

Complaints are handled separately from IP decisions. Making a complaint does not replace or pause any formal review or appeal deadlines. If you want to challenge a formal decision (for example, an objection being raised for a trade mark or patent), you need to use the separate review and appeal processes available. **For more information about this process please see here:** [**What can I do if I disagree with IP Australia's examination decision? | IP Australia First Response**](https://ipfirstresponse.ipaustralia.gov.au/options/what-can-i-do-if-i-disagree-ip-australias-examination-decision).

When making a complaint, it helps if you include: 

* your name and contact details
* details of the issue, including any reference numbers
* what outcome you are hoping for (such as an explanation, correction, or apology)
* any evidence or documents that support your complaint.

IP Australia staff are required to follow the Australian Public Service (APS) Code of Conduct. This means they must behave honestly, act with care and diligence, and treat everyone with respect and courtesy. If you feel this did not happen, you may raise that in your complaint. 

You can start by contacting IP Australia directly through their online feedback form or by using the [contact channels](https://www.ipaustralia.gov.au/about-us/contact-us)  on their website. If you are not satisfied with the response, you may take your complaint to [the Commonwealth Ombudsman](https://www.ombudsman.gov.au/complaints/how-to-make-a-complaint), who handles complaints about Australian Government agencies. The Ombudsman can review how your complaint was managed but cannot overturn IP Australia's formal decisions.

@graph.name: Want to give us feedback?
@graph.text:
Send us an [email](mailto:ipfirstresponse@ipaustralia.gov.au).\
Fill out our [feedback form](https://ipaustralia.au1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_6LKlgPWZqiheCiy).
